Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story:
Tonight is the only evening I have with Alex before he leaves for a week, and I promised we’d make it special. He’s sitting beside me, holding my hand, and I can feel how much this time means to him. I want to be present, to laugh and talk and make memories before he goes. But I’m also behind the wheel, working my shift as a taxi driver, because I couldn’t afford to take the night off. My phone buzzes with another ride request, but I ignore it, focusing on the road ahead.

Suddenly, we hit a construction detour, and the lanes squeeze together. Up ahead, a school zone sign flashes, and I spot a group of kids lingering near the curb. Alex glances at the clock, anxious about making our dinner reservation. I know he’s hoping I’ll hurry, just this once, so we don’t lose our only night together. But my training and the law are clear: slow down, be extra cautious, no matter what. My heart pounds as I grip the wheel, torn between the urge to make this night perfect for Alex and the responsibility to keep everyone safe.
